primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: God uses the 'ugly, crude cross' as a strategic instrument to deliver and restore lost sinners to His favor, specifically illustrated through the salvation of the thief on the right.

tekstueel_bewijs: God threw into our fight all that he had
Jesus snatched him out of the abyss
the Savior passed to bring our wandering souls home to God
God's mark of our deliverance and restoration to his good favor

zender.identificatie: God (The Source of Justice and Grace)

ontvanger.positie_hoorder: The hearer is invited to identify with the 'Receiver' (the thief on the right).

tekstueel_bewijs: an ugly, rude, crude, cruel cross is God's mark
this was a king... lifting them up
helper.rol_van_god: God is the Subject who uses the Cross as the Helper.
helper.rol_van_geest: Absent; the focus is on the Christological event.

tekstueel_bewijs: the wages of sin is death
a hardhearted man with nothing but a taunt
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: Sin is described as a 'fight' where God throws everything He has, and an 'abyss' from which one must be snatched.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The moral law of consequences (chickens coming home to roost) and the ethical response of the believer.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Human Being (The Thieves / The Hearer)
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The sermon establishes the 'law' of consequences first, then the 'miracle' of grace, and ends with the call to service as a result of being enriched.

voorbeelden_mens_subject: No man can run counter to God's will.

voorbeelden: offer your heart a little more willingly
he had the sense and the grace to recognize it
carried him on home to God

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: While there is a strong 'Devoir' (natural law of suffering), the climax of the sermon rests on Christ's 'Pouvoir' (His ability to save the helpless).

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: The sermon moves from S2 (The two thieves getting what they deserve) to ~S1 (The mockery of the first thief) to ~S2 (The helplessness of the second thief) and finally to S1 (Christ's substitutionary work).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: The tension is resolved by Christ occupying the center cross, taking the 'spots' (S2) to provide 'restoration' (S1).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: High. The sermon emphasizes that the thieves 'got what was coming to them' and that sin is a 'grim story'.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: Despite strong moral language regarding 'natural laws,' the core narrative engine is theocentric: Jesus is the active subject who performs the salvation that the receiver cannot perform for himself.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: There seems to be a kind of law, doesn't there? Ah, will you with me call him God?

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: Spotless, he took upon himself our spots.
Jesus snatched him out of the abyss and void, put his arm around him, and carried him on home to God.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: The thief on the right is used as an example of 'recognition,' but the focus remains on Jesus' response rather than the thief's virtue.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: The thief is not a model of 'goodness' but a model of 'emptiness' that allows God to act.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief and gratitude; a sense of being 'carried' rather than 'climbing'.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Justification by faith alone (sola fide) is narratively enacted.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The sermon successfully integrates the 'grim story' of human justice with the 'miraculous story' of divine grace.
spanning_punten: The transition from the 'law of history' (enemies of freedom toppling) to the 'miracle of the cross' is slightly jarring.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: His was a voluntary death, for the sins and wrongs of others... he took upon himself our spots.

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The sermon focuses on the objective work of Christ rather than the subjective work of the Spirit.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Severe; described as an 'abyss' and 'spots' that require a 'spotless' sacrifice.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon is structurally sound as a grace-oriented narrative. Jesus is the Subject of the salvific verbs, and the human is the Receiver.

identificatie_herstel.problematische_identificatie: The hearer might identify with the 'hard man' or 'Bogart' due to the vivid description.
identificatie_herstel.strategie: Spend more time on the 'emptiness' of the second thief to prevent the hearer from thinking 'recognition' is a work.

modale_balans.huidige_onbalans: Slightly heavy on 'Devoir' (Must) in the middle section.
modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Connect the 'Must' of suffering more explicitly to the 'Can' of Christ's victory.
modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: Show that Christ's 'Pouvoir' overcomes the 'Devoir' of death.

narratieve_hierarchie_herstel.voorgestelde_structuur: The current hierarchy (Soteriology → Ethics) is correct.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: A powerful example of theocentric preaching that uses the actantial role of Jesus as 'Savior/King' to displace human effort.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: A rhetorical analysis would focus on the imagery of the circle vs. the cross; Greimas focuses on who is doing the 'snatching' and 'carrying'.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis would look at the Greek for 'paradise'; Greimas looks at the functional role of the 'thief' as the Receiver of the 'Object' (Kingdom).
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Greimas reveals that the sermon's power comes from the 'Subject-switch' where the thief stops trying to be the Subject of his own life and becomes the Receiver of Christ's action.

volledige_subject_lijst: Jesus (snatched, put his arm, carried, took spots)
appendices.notities: The sermon uses 'Natural Law' as a bridge to 'Divine Grace,' which is a common homiletical strategy but risks moralism if the bridge is not crossed.
